column1: Which State ordinarily exercises jurisdiction in respect of crimes committed on board vessels?
column2: The coastal State
column3: The flag State
column4: All States enjoy such jurisdiction
column5: The International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea

column1: What is the meaning of justiciability?
column2: Justiciability refers to the possibility of enforcement of a particular right by the relevant rights holders
column3: Justiciability refers to the just nature or cause of a particular right
column4: Justiciability refers to the courts' assessment of whether the non-enforcement of a particular rights conforms to principles of justice
column5: Justiciability refers to the obligation of a State to enforce a particular Right

column1: In what way is Responsibility to Protect (R2P) different from humanitarian intervention?
column2: R2P is essentially the same as humanitarian intervention
column3: R2P requires a call for assistance by the State in distress
column4: R2P is less arbitrary because it requires some UNSC input and its primary objective is to avert a humanitarian crisis
column5: R2P always involves armed force, whereas humanitarian intervention does not

column1: What is the 'Lotus principle'?
column2: The so-called Lotus principle is that 'restrictions upon the independence of States cannot therefore be presumed', or, as it has been construed, 'whatever is not prohibited is permitted in international law'
column3: The so-called Lotus principle is that States are free to choose the Court that they will submit their disputes
column4: The so-called Lotus principle is that States are not prohibited to assert their enforcement jurisdiction on the high seas
column5: The so-called Lotus principle is that customary law derives from the combination of State practice and opinio juris

column1: Which of these statements best describes the UK Constitution?
column2: The UK Constitution's only source of power is that of the sovereign
column3: The UK Constitution gives the judiciary the power to overturn acts of parliament
column4: The UK Constitution is uncodified and can be found in a number of sources
column5: The UK Constitution is based on a Bill of Rights

column1: What is the obligation of the peaceful settlement of disputes?
column2: It is an obligation of result, that is, States are under a strict obligation to resolve their disputes as soon as possible
column3: It is an obligation of conduct, ie States have an obligation to try to resolve their disputes through peaceful means. This does not entail an obligation to resolve their disputes
column4: It is a peremptory norm of international law and all States have a legal interest to safeguard its application in any given dispute
column5: It is an obligation which concerns solely international courts and tribunals

column1: Which one of the following statements is false?
column2: Protocol 14 changed the committee that hears admissibility cases from a three judge to a one judge formation
column3: Protocol 14 added a new criterion for admissibility
column4: Protocol 14 abolished the Commission of Human Rights
column5: Protocol 14 extended the judicial term of office for the European Court of Human Rights

column1: Which is a 'rock' under the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)?
column2: Rocks are the islands that are less than 10 square miles
column3: Rocks are the islands that do not have any maritime zone
column4: Rocks are the islands which cannot sustain human habitation or economic life of their own and according to article 121 (3) have no Exclusive Economic Zone or continental shelf.
column5: Rocks are the small islands that can sustain human habitation

column1: What is the meaning of international legal personality?
column2: It means that only States are considered subjects of international law
column3: It means having rights and duties under international law and a capacity to enforce these by or against the relevant actor
column4: It means that an entity may challenge the authority of States
column5: It is a term that is meant to denote legal, as opposed, to physical persons under international law

column1: Which of the following is a treaty-based human rights mechanism?
column2: The UN Human Rights Committee
column3: The UN Human Rights Council
column4: The UN Universal Periodic Review
column5: The UN special mandates

column1: The UN Vienna Declaration 1993 declared that
column2: Third generation rights are of primary importance
column3: Civil and political rights are core rights
column4: All types of rights are indivisible, interrelated and interdependent
column5: Social and economic rights are non-enforceable

column1: What is the principal source of immunity in respect of international organisations (IOs)?
column2: The principal source of immunity for IOs is the UN Charter
column3: The principal sources of immunity for IOs are headquarters agreements and multilateral treaties providing specific immunities
column4: The principal source of immunity for IOs is customary law
column5: The principal source of immunity for IOs is the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Immunities

column1: Is there any hierarchy or priority among States under international law?
column2: Yes, the States that were the founding members of the United Nations are vested with more powers and authority
column3: Yes, the Permanent Five Members of the UN Security Council (UK, USA, France, Russia, China) are in a superior position than the other States
column4: No, all States are considered equal as sovereign States (the principle of sovereign equality, enshrined in article 2, para 1 UN Charter)
column5: Whether there will be any hierarchy among States is a matter of each international organization to decide

column1: What is the declaratory theory of recognition?
column2: Recognition is determinate for the existence of statehood
column3: Recognition is simply declaratory of statehood but not determinate
column4: Recognition is merely a declaration of interest
column5: Recognition requires a declaration by the newly-created State

column1: What is the function of "standard-setting in human rights diplomacy?
column2: Standard-setting means putting forward binding legal standards
column3: Standard-setting means merely proposing binding legal standards
column4: Standard-setting means putting forward non-binding legal standards
column5: Standard-setting means setting certain standards of conduct in human rights treaties

column1: What dimension did the Kadi judgment introduce with respect to the incorporation of UN Security Council resolutions?
column2: The Kadi judgment demanded that UNSC resolutions are construed in accordance with human rights
column3: The Kadi judgment demanded that all UNSC resolutions be incorporated without any further implementing legislation
column4: The Kadi judgment required that important UNSC resolutions be transformed and not merely incorporated
column5: The Kadi judgment claimed that UNSC resolutions are not binding if they violate human rights

column1: Magna Carta was
column2: An agreement in 1689 which guaranteed freedom of speech in Parliament
column3: An agreement in 1215 between the King and his barons, which guaranteed certain protections for subjects
column4: A constitutional document in the 19th century guaranteeing the right to vote
column5: A document setting a complete Bill of Rights for England

column1: Do individuals (physical) persons enjoy international legal personality in the same manner as States and international organisations?
column2: Individuals enjoy international legal personality, but this is limited
column3: Individuals enjoy unlimited international legal personality
column4: Individuals do not enjoy any international legal personality
column5: Individuals can only bring claims before international courts

column1: Is there any hierarchy or priority among the various methods of peaceful settlement of disputes?
column2: Yes, all the political methods (e.g. negotiation, mediation, inquiry, conciliation) should be exhausted prior to resorting to legal methods
column3: Legal methods prevail over the political methods, since they are binding upon the parties
column4: There is no hierarchy among these methods and the choice belongs to the disputing States
column5: It is a matter of an impartial third party to decide which method will have priority over the other

column1: Which of the following statements is false?
column2: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because it wasn't examining enough cases
column3: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because the workload had increased
column4: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because it was a part time court that could not process the growing number of complaints
column5: In the 1990's it became apparent the European Court of Human Rights had to be reformed because of the growth in the number of individuals who could access the Court after the increase in the number of member states

column1: What is the meaning of proportionality in relation to the options available to the victim State?
column2: The victim State may use the same means and intensity of force as the aggressor
column3: The victim State may use any means to defeat and incapacitate the aggressor
column4: The victim State may only use such means and force as it is necessary to defeat the aggressor
column5: The victim State can do nothing without Security Council approval

column1: What is the ordinary geographical scope of jurisdiction?
column2: Jurisdiction is ordinarily extra-territorial
column3: Jurisdiction is ordinarily on the high seas
column4: Jurisdiction is ordinarily territorial
column5: Jurisdiction is determined by the location of the offender.

column1: Which are the formal sources of international law?
column2: Custom, treaties and judicial decisions
column3: Custom, general principles of law and theory
column4: Treaties, custom and general principles of law
column5: Treaties, custom and General Assembly Resolutions

column1: What is the purpose of baselines under the law of the sea?
column2: The determination of baselines is used for the measuring of the internal waters of coastal States
column3: The determination of baselines is instrumental to the establishment of all maritime zones, since they constitute the starting point for measuring the breadth of each zone
column4: The determination of baselines is instrumental to the safe navigation of vessels on the high seas
column5: Baselines are drawn only in cases of maritime delimitation between opposing State before an international court or tribunal

column1: What is the difference between conciliation and mediation?
column2: Conciliation is the continuation of mediation with the difference that conciliation produces a binding result, while mediation not
column3: Conciliation is conducted exclusively by representatives of the UN Secretary-General, while mediation may also be conducted by third States' officials
column4: Mediation is usually conducted by a person appointed with the consent of the parties, while conciliation involves a commission, which proceeds to an impartial examination of the dispute and proposes settlement terms
column5: Conciliation is a method of dispute settlement pursued only by virtue of a treaty, while mediation may also be on an ad hoc basis

column1: In Osman v UK (1998), the European Court laid down a test, which can be used to apply a general positive obligation on a state. Which of the following statements is not part of the Osman test?
column2: The risk must emanate from a state agent
column3: If a real and imminent risk (of death/harm)
column4: A state should take reasonable steps to prevent death/harm occurring
column5: A state knows or ought to have known

column1: Who is entitled to request an advisory opinion of the ICJ?
column2: Only the principal organs of the UN may request an advisory opinion (Security Council, General Assembly, ECOSOC, Trusteeship Council, Secretariat)
column3: All international organizations may request an advisory opinion
column4: The General Assembly and the Security Council may request advisory opinions on any legal question, as well as 'other organs of the United Nations and specialized agencies, which may at any time be so authorized by the General Assembly, may also request advisory opinions of the Court on legal questions arising within the scope of their activities'
column5: The principal organs of the UN may request an advisory opinion as well as the State that have been authorized by the General Assembly

column1: What is the purpose of universal jurisdiction?
column2: Its aim is to establish certain offences as universal
column3: Its aim is to deter the commission of certain international crimes
column4: Its aim is to provide jurisdiction to all States in respect of particular crimes
column5: Its aim is to provide jurisdiction to all States in respect of all international crimes

column1: Are all acts of State organs attributed to the State under the law international responsibility?
column2: The conduct of any State organ shall be considered an act of that State, even in the case that this conduct was unauthorized or ultra vires
column3: Only the conduct of the higher echelons of the government of State shall be attributable to it
column4: The conduct of any State organs shall be considered an act of that State, provided that it is intra vires
column5: Only the conduct of the executive branch of the State shall be considered an act of that State.

column1: What is a 'treaty' according to the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties (VCLT)?
column2: Treaties are all agreements concluded between States, international organizations and non-State entities (e.g. corporations)
column3: Treaties are agreements concluded between States in written form and governed by international law
column4: Treaties are both the written and oral agreements between States
column5: Treaties are agreements concluded between States in written form governed either by international or domestic law

column1: Is the unlawful homicide committed by Minister of country X abroad an act jure imperii or jure gestionis?
column2: Such conduct is a public act (jure imperii)
column3: Such conduct never attracts immunity
column4: Such conduct is a private act (jure gestionis)
column5: Such conduct is a public act but is shielded by immunity

column1: What was the outcome before the European Court of Human Rights in the Al-Adsani case?
column2: The Court held that the right to a fair trial trumped the privilege of immunity
column3: The Court held that immunity trumped the right to a fair trial
column4: The Court held that immunities were not in conflict with the right to a fair trial
column5: The Court held that human rights considerations prevailed over all other contrary rules of international law, including most immunities

column1: What other criteria were imposed by the Badinter Commission on the former Yugoslav republics?
column2: The Commission required a commitment to submit disputes to the ICJ
column3: The Commission required a change in boundaries
column4: The Commission required a commitment to human rights and democracy
column5: The Commission required an exchange of ethnic populations

column1: How treaties are to be interpreted?
column2: Treaties are to be interpreted in good faith in accordance with the ordinary meaning to be given to the terms of the treaty in their context and in the light of its object and purpose
column3: Treaties are to be interpreted only in accordance with the ordinary meaning of their terms
column4: Treaties are to be interpreted in accordance with the intention of the parties, as evidenced in the preparatory works of the treaty
column5: Treaties are to be interpreted only in light of its object and purpose

column1: When coastal States do enforce their criminal jurisdiction over foreign vessels in their ports?
column2: Port States generally do not enforce their criminal jurisdiction over crimes that do not infringe their customs laws or disrupt peace and public order.
column3: Port States enforce their jurisdiction in all cases of delinquent vessels
column4: Port States enforce their jurisdiction only in respect of very serious crimes, such as drug trafficking
column5: Port States are not entitled to enforce their jurisdiction over any foreign vessel

column1: What is the value of the Resolutions of the UN General Assembly in terms as a 'source' of international law?
column2: GA Resolutions are considered as additional sources of international law and thus binding upon States
column3: GA Resolutions are equivalent to treaties
column4: GA Resolutions reflect always customary law
column5: GA Resolutions are considered as material source, in the sense that they may enunciate statements of customary law

column1: Do treaties bind third States, ie non-State parties?
column2: Treaties may create only rights for third States
column3: Treaties create both obligations and rights for third States
column4: Treaties do no create obligations or rights for third States without their consent
column5: Treaties do not create any obligations or rights for third States, even when the latter consent.

column1: Which of the following articles are not qualified rights?
column2: Article 3
column3: Article 8
column4: Article 9
column5: Article 11

column1: What is dualism?
column2: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are part of a unified legal system
column3: Under dualism, international and domestic laws comprise distinct legal Systems
column4: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are distinct but equal in hierarchy
column5: Dualism suggests that international and domestic law are distinct legal systems whereby domestic law always prevails

column1: What is an act jure imperii?
column2: An act is jure imperii when undertaken by an international organisation
column3: An act is jure imperii when undertaken in an official State capacity
column4: All acts undertaken by State officials are acts jure imperii
column5: An act is jure imperii when undertaken by a State corporation

column1: What is the relationship between the formal sources of international law?
column2: There is no hierarchy between the formal sources of international law
column3: Treaties supersede custom
column4: Custom supersedes treaties
column5: General Principles of Law supersede both custom and treaties

column1: What was the particular advantage of UNSC Resolution 678 over a collective defensive action under Article 51 UN Charter during the Gulf War?
column2: Resolution 678 allowed the allies to attack Iraq with nuclear and chemical weapons
column3: Resolution 678 is narrower than the inherent right of self-defence under Article 51 UN Charter
column4: Resolution 678 was faster to adopt and negotiate.
column5: Resolution 678 is broader because it authorised the use of force with respect to any matter threatening the peace and security of the Gulf region.

column1: How can customary law be related to treaty provisions?
column2: Treaties may only codify customary law
column3: Customary law is a different source of international and it cannot be embodied in treaties
column4: Treaties may 1) codify customary law, 2) 'crystallise' customary law, 3) lead to the emergence of customary law
column5: Customary law can emerge only from few multilateral treaties

column1: What does it mean for a State to be sovereign?
column2: Sovereignty means being recognised by all other States
column3: Sovereignty means to be able to enter into treaties and join the UN
column4: Sovereignty means freedom to determine one's own affairs without external interference
column5: Sovereignty means possessing the right to defend oneself

column1: What is the meaning of functional recognition?
column2: Recognition is a function as opposed to a power
column3: Recognition is reciprocal between two States
column4: Recognition is only afforded to particular administrative acts not to the entity's declared statehood
column5: Recognition is only afforded to the government, not the State

column1: What is the meaning of "act of State" doctrine?
column2: The act of State doctrine denotes that all State acts attract immunity
column3: The act of State doctrine denotes that the assessment as to the existence of an alleged tort committed by a State belongs to the executive and not the courts
column4: The act of State doctrine denotes that the courts are well placed to assess the existence of an alleged tort committed by the State
column5: The act of State doctrine is a legal mechanism that allows the courts to provide immunity to public acts of foreign States

column1: How can the structure of the international society be displayed?
column2: The structure of the international society follows the vertical model of the domestic legal orders
column3: International society consists of a constellation of sovereign States and other international organizations, which are dispersed in a rather horizontal order of authority
column4: International society is so anarchical that there is no order of authority, neither vertical nor horizontal
column5: The structure of the international society resembles the structure of the most powerful nations in the world

column1: Are there any limitations to the incorporation of customary crimes under English law?
column2: There are no limitations to the incorporation of customary crimes
column3: Customary crimes must be contained in a multilateral treaty in order to be automatically incorporated
column4: The courts may freely incorporate customary crimes into the domestic sphere
column5: The situation is not clear-cut but an act of parliament would most probably be required

column1: What is the function of the contiguous zone?
column2: The contiguous zone functions as security zone of the coastal State
column3: The contiguous zone is a zone, in which the coastal State may explore and exploit its mineral resources
column4: The contiguous zone is a zone in which the coastal State is permitted to prevent and punish infringements of customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws
column5: The contiguous zone is a zone in which the coastal State safeguards its archaeological and historical objects

column1: Which of the examples below has not been developed by the European Court of Human Rights as a situation where the state has a positive obligation to protect?
column2: When the applicant is in the custody of the state
column3: Where the state must investigate claims against it
column4: The development of a legal framework to protect those within the state
column5: To provide housing for all those homeless within a state

column1: Which case was the first to define the meaning of the doctrine of 'margin of appreciation' as applied by the European Court of Human Rights?
column2: Goodwin v UK (2002)
column3: Airey v Ireland (1979)
column4: Osman v UK ( 1998)
column5: Handyside v UK (1976)

column1: How are the members of the arbitral tribunal appointed?
column2: All the members of the arbitral tribunal are appointed by the parties
column3: All the members of the arbitral tribunal are appointed by the parties
column4: All the members of the arbitral tribunal are appointed by an impartial third party, such as the president of the ICJ
column5: All the members of the arbitral tribunal are appointed by the parties from a restricted list of arbitrators

column1: Are the peremptory norms of international law the only norms that set out obligations erga omnes?
column2: Yes
column3: No, acts of international organizations also set out such obligations
column4: No, decisions of international courts also set out such obligations
column5: No, even though all peremptory norms set out obligations erga omnes, the latter may also spring from treaties regulating objective regimes or unilateral acts

column1: What is the constitutive theory of recognition?
column2: Recognition is determinative of statehood
column3: Recognition requires constitutional approval by third nations
column4: Recognition requires that the constitution of the recognised State includes sufficient human rights guarantees
column5: Countries wishing to be recognised must possess a valid constitution

column1: The enforcement mechanism of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (and Protocol) consists of
column2: A reporting mechanism only
column3: Judgment of an international tribunal
column4: Right to individual petition only
column5: A reporting mechanism and right to individual petition

column1: Is piracy under international (jure gentium) law subject to universal jurisdiction?
column2: Piracy jure gentium is subject to flag State jurisdiction
column3: Piracy jure gentium is subject to universal jurisdiction
column4: Piracy jure gentium is subject to port State jurisdiction
column5: Piracy jure gentium is subject to nationality-based jurisdiction

column1: What are self-executing treaties?
column2: Self-executing treaties are adopted only by the executive
column3: Self-executive treaties are clear and precise enough so as not to require any further implementing measures
column4: Self-executing rely on implementing measures stipulated in the treaty Itself
column5: Self-executing treaties follow the doctrine of transformation

column1: Is the ICJ hostile to the idea that an armed attack may arise through a series of lower intensity, yet cumulative, instances of armed force?
column2: The ICJ was not hostile to the accumulation theory
column3: The concept of an armed attack refers to a single attack, not multiple smaller instances of armed force
column4: In the Nicaragua case the ICJ dismissed the accumulation theory
column5: The ICJ has never addressed this issue

column1: Is there any priority among international courts and tribunals?
column2: According to the lis pendens rule, the court or the tribunal that seizes first the dispute has exclusive jurisdiction to adjudicate it
column3: The International Court of Justice has by definition priority over any other court or tribunal
column4: Since there is no lis pendens rule in international law and all depends on the consent of the parties to a dispute, there is no priority or hierarchy among international courts and tribunals
column5: Regional or special courts have priority over all others in line of the principle of lex specialis

column1: Do third States enjoy any fishing rights within the Exclusive Economic Zone of another State?
column2: When the coastal State cannot harvest the 'total allowable catch', the coastal State is to give other State access to that surplus with priority to be given to developing and land-locked States
column3: Third States may never have access to fisheries within another State's EEZ
column4: The coastal State is to give access to fisheries within its EEZ only to neighbouring States
column5: Third States are free to fish within another EEZ, except from certain designated areas

column1: What is the purpose of sovereign immunity?
column2: The purpose of immunity is to protect foreign Heads of State from embarrassment
column3: Immunity protects a State from being invaded by another
column4: Immunity shields States from being sued in the courts of other States
column5: The purpose of immunity is to offer impunity in respect of all crimes

column1: What is passive personality jurisdiction?
column2: It is jurisdiction based on the nationality of the offender
column3: It is jurisdiction based on where the offence was committed
column4: It is jurisdiction based on the nationality of the victims
column5: It is jurisdiction based on the country where the legal person was Registered

column1: Which of the following types of rights have been described as first generation rights?
column2: Social and economic rights
column3: Civil and political rights
column4: Cultural rights
column5: People's rights

column1: What is the problem of 'fragmentation' of international law?
column2: Fragmentation of international law concerns the possibility of different legal regimes apply the same rules of international law
column3: It is possible for several legal regimes (ie foreign investment law and human rights law) to exist and develop in isolation of each other, ultimately culminating in the production of divergent rules of international law
column4: Fragmentation is when States assume different interpretations of the same rule of international law
column5: Fragmentation is when States disagree to abide by a certain rule of international law

column1: What is functional (ratione materiae) immunity?
column2: Functional immunity covers the person but not the act
column3: Functional immunity covers the act and incidentally also the person committing the act
column4: Functional immunity covers the State and incidentally also the act
column5: Functional immunity covers both private and public acts as long as they are sanctioned by the State

column1: What is the meaning of implied authorisation?
column2: Presumption of Security Council approval of armed force when a State has been forewarned
column3: Implicit authorisation on the basis of a specific number of votes by UNSC members
column4: Presumption that all unlawful attacks will be subject to armed force by a resolution of the UNSC
column5: In cases of repeated unlawful attacks the UNSC shall authorise neighbouring States to take whatever measures they deem necessary to rectify the situation

column1: Which philosopher called the idea of natural rights 'nonsense on stilts'?
column2: Alan Gerwith
column3: Emmanuel Kant
column4: John Locke
column5: Jeremy Bentham

column1: Who has the authority to conclude a treaty on the part of States?
column2: Treaties are concluded by the competent representatives of States. Heads of States, heads of governments, ministers of foreign affairs and heads of diplomatic missions are presumed to have such authority
column3: Treaties may only negotiated and concluded by the heads of State and ministers of foreign affairs
column4: Treaties are negotiated and signed only by the persons that bear the necessary 'full powers' and no person is presumed to hold such authority
column5: Treaties are concluded only by members of the diplomatic missions of States

column1: Who is a 'persistent objector'?
column2: The State which persistently objects to the rule in question after its formation
column3: The State which denies to be bound by the rule in question for a short period
column4: The State which persistently and publicly objects to the formation of a rule of customary law from its outset
column5: The State which accepts the formation of a rule of customary law but it retains objections as to its content

column1: What is the meaning of collective security?
column2: The right to self-defence by more than one nation acting in concert
column3: The right of one's allies to defend the victim State
column4: The authorisation of armed force by the UN Security Council
column5: The authorisation of peacekeeping missions by the UN General Assembly

column1: The European Convention on Human Rights is predominantly concerned with which of the following?
column2: Economic and social rights
column3: Environmental rights
column4: Civil and political rights
column5: Economic freedom

column1: Is the jurisdiction of international tribunals regulated by the same principles applicable to national courts?
column2: The jurisdictional principles applicable to national courts are also common to international tribunals
column3: The jurisdiction of all international tribunals is regulated by the UN Security Council
column4: International tribunals share some, but not all, of the jurisdictional principles applicable to national courts
column5: The jurisdiction of international tribunals is dictated solely by their founding treaties

column1: What is the meaning of collective rights?
column2: Collective rights belong to distinct groups of people
column3: Collective rights are those that belong to particular groups as opposed to the individual members of the group
column4: Minority rights are collective rights
column5: Collective rights entail a right of the group as such as well as individual rights of the group's members

column1: Are States under any obligation when they conduct negotiations?
column2: States are under no obligation as to how they conduct their negotiation
column3: States are under an obligation so to conduct themselves that the negotiations are meaningful
column4: States are under an obligation to find a solution of the dispute whenever they conduct negotiations
column5: States are under an obligation to inform the UN Secretary-General about the progress of their negotiations

column1: What is the major difference between naturalism and positivism?
column2: On the one hand, naturalism is based on a set of rules that are of universal and objective scope and on the other hand, positivism is based on a structured and coherent legal system that is created by States in light of their interests and desires
column3: While naturalism serves only the theory human rights law, positivism has a wider and more general scope
column4: Naturalism concerns the underpinning values of the international society, while positivism the international rules as such
column5: Naturalism is a school of thought advocated outside of Europe, while positivism is Euro-centric theory

column1: What is an 'internationally wrongful conduct'?
column2: An international wrongful conduct is an action or omission which is in breach of a rule of international criminal law
column3: An international wrongful conduct is every breach of an international obligation of the State, whether attributable to it or not
column4: An internationally wrongful conduct consists of an action or omission attributable to the State, which constitutes a breach of an international obligation of the State
column5: An internationally wrongful conduct is the conduct that cannot be excused on grounds of necessity, force majeure etc.

column1: What is the effects doctrine?
column2: It posits that jurisdiction exists only when it is effective
column3: The effects doctrine serves to confer jurisdiction on the State which has an effective link with the harmful conduct
column4: The effects doctrine serves to confer jurisdiction on the State sharing the nationality of the offender
column5: The effects doctrine serves to confer jurisdiction to the State on whose territory the conduct produces effects

column1: Which persons are considered as 'de facto' organs of the State under the law of international responsibility?
column2: 'De facto organs' are the individuals that are empowered by law to exercise elements of governmental authority
column3: 'De facto organs' are the persons, which are, in fact, acting on the instructions of, or under the direction or control of, that State in carrying out the conduct attributable to the State
column4: 'De facto organs' are the de jure organs of the State that act without due authority or ultra vires
column5: 'De facto organs' are the organs, whose acts or omission cannot be attributed to the State

column1: What is the fundamental prerequisite for the incorporation of custom under English law?
column2: Custom is incorporated if it is not in conflict with existing legislation
column3: Custom is superior to English law and is always incorporated
column4: Custom must first be recognised by Parliament before the courts can bring it into the domestic sphere
column5: Custom is incorporated with the passing of implementing legislation

column1: Was the use of armed force permitted prior to the United Nations Charter?
column2: Armed force was prohibited
column3: Armed force was permitted with no restrictions
column4: Armed force was permitted subject to few restrictions
column5: Armed force was not regulated under international law prior to 1945

column1: What is the protective principle of jurisdiction?
column2: It is jurisdiction based on the harm to national interests by conduct committed abroad
column3: It is jurisdiction in order to protect one's nationals abroad
column4: It is jurisdiction in order to protect international human rights
column5: It is jurisdiction based on the nationality of the offender

column1: Which one of the following statements is correct?
column2: The Council of Europe was established in 1950 and consists of 27 member states
column3: The Council of Europe was established in 1949 and consists of 47 member states
column4: The Council of Europe was established in 1959 and consists of 34 member states
column5: The Council of Europe was established in 1984 and consists of 19 member states

column1: What is the 'equitable result' in the law and practice of maritime delimitation?
column2: It is the only method of delimitation that international courts and tribunals follow
column3: An equitable result is what a judge or the arbitrator would decide ex aequo et bono, i.e. upon their discretion and in light of what they consider as fair and equitable in a delimitation case
column4: It is the end result that all delimitations of areas of continental shelf and EEZ should achieve, after, however, drawing a provisional 'equidistance line' and adjusting the zone in the light of the relevant circumstances and the proportionality test.
column5: Achieving an equitable result is an old method of delimitation which is currently not applicable

column1: What is a derogation?
column2: Derogations are exemptions from particular human rights obligations contained in a treaty
column3: A derogation refers to the ability of rights holders to bring a claim against the State for breach of an obligation
column4: A State may suspend particular rights by means of a derogation in circumstances that threaten its existence
column5: Derogations are enforcement clauses in human rights treaties

column1: What is an act jure gestionis?
column2: Acts jure gestionis are those undertaken by States in a private capacity
column3: All purchases by the State are acts jure gestionis
column4: All acts undertaken by State corporations are jure gestionis
column5: All conduct undertaken by government officials in their free time is considered jus gestionis.

column1: What is the meaning of cultural relativism?
column2: Culture relativism posits that human rights apply equally to all without restrictions
column3: Culture relativism posits that human rights have a cultural origin
column4: Cultural relativism posits that the application of human rights is relative to the laws in each nation
column5: Cultural relativism posits that local culture should validate the existence and practice of all human rights

column1: Is recognition of governments prevalent in contemporary international practice?
column2: Recognition of governments is very prevalent in contemporary practice
column3: Recognition of governments has largely been replaced by functional Recognition
column4: Government recognition is common in respect of rebel entities
column5: Only democratic governments are recognised in contemporary practice

column1: What is the legal nature of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR)?
column2: The UDHR is a multilateral treaty
column3: The UDHR is a UN General Assembly resolution
column4: The UDHR is a UN Security Council resolution
column5: The UDHR is a declaration adopted by several States at an international conference

column1: Under what circumstances do human rights violations taking place outside the territory of ECHR member States fall within the remit of the ECHR?
column2: The ECHR applies outside Europe where human rights are violated by ECHR member States abroad
column3: The ECHR applies extraterritorially in circumstances where a member State exercises effective control
column4: The ECHR applies extraterritorially where a member State has contributed forces to a UN peacekeeping mission
column5: The ECHR applies extraterritorially where human rights violations are taking place in former colonies of member States

column1: What does the principle 'pacta sunt servanda' mean?
column2: Parties to a treaty should be cognizant of its terms and not misinterpret them
column3: Parties to a treaty should safeguard the object and purpose of the treaty
column4: Parties to a treaty should adhere to its terms in good faith
column5: Parties to a treaty should not violate the most important provisions of the treaty

column1: What was the consequence from the absence of implementing legislation in the Tin Council case?
column2: The International Tin Council was headquartered in London and hence the absence of implementing legislation was inconsequential
column3: The constitutive treaties of international organisations are subject to the doctrine of incorporation
column4: The absence of implementing legislation with respect to the Council's founding treaty meant that individuals did not derive rights and duties from it in the English legal system
column5: The absence of implementing legislation in England in respect of an international organisation is inconsequential under international law

column1: Which of the following statements is true?
column2: The Human Rights Act 1998 incorporates the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law
column3: The Human Rights Act 1998 allows a court to invalidate primary legislation
column4: The Human Rights Act 1998 allows any person with a reasonable case to bring a case before a court
column5: The Human Rights Act 1998 incorporates the EU charter of fundamental rights into UK law

column1: What forms may the obligation of reparation take?
column2: Reparation may take only the form of pecuniary compensation, including the interest
column3: Reparation denotes only the physical restitution of the wrongful act
column4: Reparation includes restitution, compensation, and satisfaction, either alone or alongside other forms of reparation
column5: The form of reparation is a matter for the responsible State to decide

column1: What is jus cogens?
column2: They are peremptory norms of international law, from which no derogations are allowed and which can never be altered even with the consent of the States
column3: They are rules of international law that are laid down in multilateral treaties with a wide participation
column4: They are the decisions of the UN Security Council
column5: They are the rules of international law on which the ICJ founds its decisions

column1: What is 'unilateral acts'?
column2: They are acts that States perform as practice in the context of custom
column3: They are acts creating unilateral legal obligations to the acting State
column4: Unilateral acts are simply political acts of State devoid of any legal effect
column5: Unilateral acts are those that State perform in order to be bound by a treaty

column1: Is extra-territorial abduction a ground for refusal of otherwise lawful jurisdiction by English courts?
column2: Such abduction constitutes abuse of process and leads to a stay of proceedings
column3: Such abduction gives rise to the abductor's liability but does not lead to a stay of proceedings
column4: The stay of proceedings under such circumstances would prevent the administration of justice in respect of international criminals
column5: The courts may, but will seldom, stay proceedings in cases of extra-territorial abduction

column1: What is the meaning of 'secondary rules' in the law of international responsibility?
column2: Secondary rules are the rules of interpretation of international law, including the law of international responsibility
column3: Secondary rules are the rules that govern the legal consequences arising from a breach of the primary rules, ie of the international obligations of the States
column4: Secondary rules are the rules that govern exclusively the concept of attribution in the law of international responsibility
column5: Secondary rules are the rules that govern exclusively the law of countermeasures

column1: What does the doctrine of incorporation suggest in respect of treaties?
column2: The doctrine of incorporation requires that all treaties undergo legislative transformation before they become domestic law
column3: The doctrine of incorporation does not require any further action at the domestic level
column4: The doctrine of incorporation treats treaties as inferior to domestic law
column5: The doctrine of incorporation suggests that ratified treaties automatically pass into the sphere of domestic law

column1: Are the provisional measures issued by the ICJ binding upon the parties?
column2: No, according to the literal interpretation of the relevant provision of the State, the provisional measures are not binding
column3: No, unless the parties have agreed so beforehand
column4: It depends upon the Court whether the provisional measures will be binding
column5: Yes, it has been consistently held by the Court since the La Grand case (2001) that they are binding

column1: When are countermeasures illegal?
column2: Countermeasures are illegal when inter alia are disproportionate or in violation of a peremptory norm of international law (e.g. the use of force, human rights)
column3: Countermeasures are illegal when they are taken in the course of an armed conflict
column4: Countermeasures are illegal when they violate bilateral treaties
column5: Countermeasures are illegal when the responsible State does not consent to them

column1: What is the difference between political and legal means of dispute settlement?
column2: The outcome arising from legal methods, ie arbitration or adjudication by the ICJ, is final and binding upon the parties, whereas this is not the case with diplomatic methods
column3: The political methods are pursued upon the consent of then parties to the dispute, whereas the legal methods not
column4: The political means lead to a final settlement of the dispute, whereas this is not the case with the legal methods
column5: The legal methods of dispute settlement are pursued only in respect of significant disputes, whereas the political means are employed in all disputes

column1: What is the rationale for the exhaustion of local remedies in international human rights?
column2: The local remedies rule aims to free up international tribunals to deal with the most serious cases
column3: The local remedies rule aims to dissuade applicants abusing the system from filing unnecessary petitions
column4: The local remedies rule aims on the one hand to restrict the volume of petitions to international tribunals while at the same time building up the capacity of local courts
column5: The local remedies rule helps demonstrate that national courts are always better placed than international ones to deal with cases

column1: Which of the following cases best illustrates the 'living instrument principle' used by the European Court of Human Rights?
column2: Golder v UK (1978)
column3: A v UK (2009)
column4: Goodwin v UK (2002)
column5: Osman v UK (1998)

column1: Is the recognition of foreign judgments subject to the same rules as those applicable to the incorporation and transformation of treaties?
column2: Foreign judgments are enforced on the basis of the doctrine of incorporation
column3: Foreign judgments are enforced on the basis of the doctrine of transformation
column4: The recognition of foreign judgments is dependent on the existence of appropriate bilateral or multilateral treaties
column5: The courts exercise discretion as to the enforcement of foreign judgments on the basis of the rule of comity

column1: What was the most important finding by the House of Lords in the Pinochet case?
column2: The Pinochet case confirmed that former heads of State enjoy absolute immunity
column3: The Pinochet case confirmed that all public acts enjoy immunity
column4: The Pinochet case confirmed that former heads of State cease to enjoy personal immunity once removed from office
column5: The Pinochet case confirmed that in respect of immunities there is no difference between a current and a former head of State

column1: Which one of the statements below is false?
column2: The war crimes trials at Nuremberg and Tokyo took place immediately after the First World War
column3: The war crimes trials introduced a 'crime against humanity' as an offence
column4: The war crimes trials held individuals legally responsible for acts such as war crimes and crimes against humanity
column5: The war crimes trials found that "superior orders" could not be used as a defence for war crimes or crimes against humanity

column1: Which State exercises jurisdiction over vessels on the high seas?
column2: All States may exercise jurisdiction over foreign vessels on the high seas
column3: States may exercise jurisdiction over foreign vessels on the high seas only in cases of criminal activity that concerns them
column4: The flag State is to exercise exclusive jurisdiction over its vessels on the high seas, with the exception of specific cases, such as piracy
column5: The flag State is the only State to exercise exclusive jurisdiction over its vessels on the high seas with no exception

column1: Should treaties assume a particular form?
column2: Treaties should always be designated as such and assume a particular form
column3: Treaties should always assume a particular form, no matter how they are designated
column4: Treaties do not have to assume a particular form or designated as such
column5: Treaties have to be designated as such, no matter what form they assume

column1: What is the fundamental premise of monist theory?
column2: Monism posits that international law is superior to domestic laws
column3: Monism posits that international and domestic law are part of the same legal order
column4: Monism posits that domestic laws are superior to international law
column5: Monism posits that domestic and international law never clash

column1: Where do we find the 'general principles of law recognized by civilized nations' (article 38 ICJ Statute)?
column2: We look for established principles of law recognized only among the most civilised nations
column3: We look for established principles of law, which are common to all major legal systems
column4: We look for general principles of international law recognized by international courts and tribunals
column5: We look for general principles of law recognized by all nations

column1: When does an illegal act of violence on the high seas fall short of qualifying as piracy?
column2: When it is committed against a public vessel of another State
column3: When it is committed for 'private ends'
column4: When it is committed by a warship even when its crew has mutinied and taken control of the ship
column5: When it is not committed against another vessel and when it is not committed for 'private ends'

column1: What is the meaning of "armed attack" in Article 51 UN Charter?
column2: Armed attack includes all types of armed force
column3: Armed attack includes all high intensity instances of armed force
column4: Armed attack includes terrorist attacks
column5: An "armed attack" gives the right to invade the aggressor State

column1: Who is an 'injured State' in the law of international responsibility?
column2: A State is 'injured' in case that it has suffered a damage from the internationally wrongful conduct
column3: A State is 'injured' in cases that there has been a violation of a peremptory norm of international law
column4: A State is 'injured' should it acknowledge the existence of the internationally wrongful conduct
column5: A State is 'injured' if the obligation breached was owed to it individually or if it was owed to a group of States, including that State, and it was specially affected

column1: What is personal (ratione personae) immunity?
column2: Personal immunity is afforded to all physical persons
column3: Personal immunity is that which is afforded in a personal capacity and hence does not cover conduct of the State as such
column4: Personal immunity is afforded only to particular persons irrespective if their conduct was undertaken in a private or public capacity
column5: Personal immunity is afforded to State officials for conduct undertaken in a public capacity

column1: Which of the following statements best describes the UN Human Rights Council?
column2: The UN Human Rights Council has the power to impose economic sanctions on a state for human rights violations
column3: The UN Human Rights Council scrutinises the human rights records of member states on the Council and each member state of the UN
column4: The UN Human Rights Council replaced the Economic and Social Committee of the UN
column5: The UN Human Rights Council consists of 27 member states

column1: When a reservation is considered as invalid under the law of treaties?
column2: A reservation is invalid when the majority of the State parties objects to it
column3: A reservation is invalid only when an international tribunal says so
column4: A reservation is invalid only when is incompatible with a peremptory norm of international law (jus cogens)
column5: A reservation is invalid when it is incompatible with the object and purpose of the treaty

column1: What kind of rights do coastal States enjoy over their continental shelf?
column2: The coastal State enjoy ipso facto and ab initio sovereign rights over its continental shelf for the purpose of exploring it and exploiting its natural resources
column3: The coastal State may exercise sovereign rights over its continental shelf only upon its declaration
column4: The coastal State exercise sovereign rights over its continental shelf for the purpose of exploiting its fishing resources
column5: The coastal State may exercise only limited rights over its continental shelf and only upon the consent of its neighbouring States

column1: Are there any limits to the application of article 103 of the UN Charter?
column2: No, there are no limits to article 103
column3: Yes, Article 103 cannot trump multilateral treaties
column4: Yes, article 103 of the UN Charter cannot trump jus cogens norms
column5: Yes, when a case is submitted to the ICJ, article 103 ceases to have any effect

column1: Can countries rely on their domestic law as an excuse to violate their obligations under international law?
column2: Domestic law always prevails over international law
column3: Only customary international law prevails over domestic law
column4: Obligations under international law prevail over domestic law
column5: Constitutional obligations always prevail over obligations under international law

column1: What is meant by an international organisation's implied powers?
column2: Implied are those powers which are necessary in order for an organisation to carry out the tasks conferred upon it and which are not stipulated in its charter
column3: It refers to new powers assumed unilaterally by the organisation
column4: It refers to powers conferred upon the organisation by the international Community
column5: Implied powers are those whose determination depends on an expansive interpretation of an organisation's charter

column1: What are the criteria for statehood under the 1933 Montevideo Convention?
column2: It requires that the entity in question is not an aggressor and that it is peaceful
column3: It requires recognition by the majority of other nations
column4: It requires a permanent population, a defined territory, a government and a capacity to enter into foreign relations
column5: It requires stable and indissoluble borders as well as recognition
